

<img src="https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcQn1sQfoi9DskxbeZaA_9AoL17NFl2MJPdQXOH4MuckjFL3uZCC:https://circuitdigest.com/sites/default/files/circuitdiagram_mic/Circuit-Diagram-of-Interfacing-Arduino-with-Membrane-Keypad.jpg&amp;s" alt="What&#39;s Inside a 4x4 Membrane Keypad and ..."/>

# Arduino-fall-Assignment
#include <Keypad.h>

const char number_of_rows = 4;
const char number_of_columns = 4;

char row_pins[number_of_rows] = {2, 3, 4, 5};
char column_pins[number_of_columns] = {6, 7, 8, 9};

char key_array[number_of_rows][number_of_columns] = {  
  {'1', '2', '3', 'A'},
  {'4', '5', '6', 'B'},
  {'7', '8', '9', 'C'},
  {'*', '0', '#', 'D'}
  };

Keypad k = Keypad(makeKeymap(key_array),row_pins , column_pins, number_of_rows, number_of_columns);

void setup()
{
  Serial.begin(9600);
}

void loop()
{
  char key_pressed = k.getKey();
  if(key_pressed)
  {
    Serial.println(key_pressed);
  }
}
  
<img src="data:image/jpeg;base64," alt="Arduino 4x4 Keypad Interfacing With ..."/><img width="259" height="194" alt="image" src="https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f257fc21-ec5e-4416-879d-9a31cce3fa8e" />

First the code tells the arduino how many rows and columns the keypad has. It then creates a layout that mateches each of the buttons from 1-9, #, and A-D. Then it sees which arduino pins are connected to the keypads columns and rows. It uses the info to scan the keypad and detect the button presses. In the loop it is constantly checking is a key if pressed and if it is it goes to the Serial Moniter. This is what allows you to see what button you pressed in real time.



https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7f573fd7-9f3f-4017-8fc1-0afdfca2663f
